articles.headline: A Protest? A Vigil? In Beijing, Anxious Crowds Are Unsure How Far to Go.
articles.snippet: In a country where protests are swiftly quashed, many who gathered to voice their discontent — under the watchful eye of the police — were uncertain about how far to go.
articles.abstract: In a country where protests are swiftly quashed, many who gathered to voice their discontent — under the watchful eye of the police — were uncertain about how far to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The crowd was hard to make out at first, a dark mass huddled along the Beijing riverbank after sunset. The people stood quietly, almost nervously, dozens bundled in thick coats beside yellowed willow trees. At their center was a small altar, strewn with candles and flowers, for the 10 people who died in a fire in western China last week.

articles.headline: Sympathy, and Job Offers, for Twitter’s Misinformation Experts
articles.snippet: Seeing false and toxic information as a potentially expensive liability, companies in and outside the tech industry are angling to hire people who can keep it in check.
articles.abstract: Seeing false and toxic information as a potentially expensive liability, companies in and outside the tech industry are angling to hire people who can keep it in check.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the weeks since Elon Musk took over Twitter, dozens of people responsible for keeping dangerous or inaccurate material in check on the service have posted on LinkedIn that they resigned or lost their jobs. Their statements have drawn a flood of condolences — and attempts to recruit them.

articles.headline: Elon Musk Takes On Apple’s Power, Setting Up a Clash
articles.snippet: In a series of tweets on Monday, Mr. Musk accused Apple of threatening to pull Twitter from its App Store and of trying to censor.
articles.abstract: In a series of tweets on Monday, Mr. Musk accused Apple of threatening to pull Twitter from its App Store and of trying to censor.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — “What’s going on here @tim_cook?” Elon Musk tweeted on Monday to Tim Cook, the chief executive of Apple, igniting a spat between the world’s richest man and the world’s most valuable public company.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Tripp Mickle

articles.headline: Antiwar Activists Who Flee Russia Find Detention, Not Freedom, in the U.S.
articles.snippet: Thousands of Russians are crossing the U.S. southern border to claim asylum. Many are ending up in immigration prison. “I left Russia for a place just like Russia,” said one.
articles.abstract: Thousands of Russians are crossing the U.S. southern border to claim asylum. Many are ending up in immigration prison. “I left Russia for a place just like Russia,” said one.
articles.lead_paragraph: PINE PRAIRIE, La. — They had fallen in love their first year in medical school in Russia, joined by their commitment to building democracy in a country where any remaining hope of it was disappearing.

articles.headline: Chinese Unrest Over Lockdown Upends Global Economic Outlook
articles.snippet: Growing protests in the world’s biggest manufacturing nation add a new element of uncertainty atop the Ukraine war, an energy crisis and inflation.
articles.abstract: Growing protests in the world’s biggest manufacturing nation add a new element of uncertainty atop the Ukraine war, an energy crisis and inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The swelling protests against severe pandemic restrictions in China — the world’s second-largest economy — are injecting a new element of uncertainty and instability into the global economy when nations are already struggling to manage the fallout from a war in Ukraine, an energy crisis and painful inflation.

articles.headline: Jewish Allies Call Trump’s Dinner With Antisemites a Breaking Point
articles.snippet: Supporters who looked past the former president’s admirers in bigoted corners of the far right, and his own use of antisemitic tropes, now are drawing a line. “He legitimizes Jew hatred and Jew haters,” says one. “And this scares me.”
articles.abstract: Supporters who looked past the former president’s admirers in bigoted corners of the far right, and his own use of antisemitic tropes, now are drawing a line. “He legitimizes Jew hatred and Jew haters,” says one. “And this scares me.”
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of Donald J. Trump’s presidency, Jewish Republicans rationalized away the bigoted fringe of Mr. Trump’s coalition, arguing that the unsavory supporters in his midst and the antisemitic tropes he deployed paled in comparison with the staunchly pro-Israel policies of his administration.

articles.headline: Russian Retreat Reveals Signs of an Atrocity in a Ukrainian Village
articles.snippet: In the southern Kherson region, the pattern seen in eastern Ukraine is repeating: The withdrawal of Russian forces yields evidence of possible war crimes.
articles.abstract: In the southern Kherson region, the pattern seen in eastern Ukraine is repeating: The withdrawal of Russian forces yields evidence of possible war crimes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRAVDYNE, Ukraine — First came small pieces of bone. Then a pair of arms tied at the wrists with rope.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O'Reilly

articles.headline: As Haiti Unravels, U.S. Officials Push to Send in an Armed Foreign Force
articles.snippet: Fearing a mass exodus, some Biden officials are pressing for a multinational force, but they don’t want to send U.S. troops and haven’t been able to persuade other countries to take the lead.
articles.abstract: Fearing a mass exodus, some Biden officials are pressing for a multinational force, but they don’t want to send U.S. troops and haven’t been able to persuade other countries to take the lead.
articles.lead_paragraph: After days of gunfights in early November, Haitian police officers emerged triumphant: They had finally liberated the nation’s biggest port from the gangs that had taken it over for two months.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Adriana Zehbrauskas

articles.headline: ‘No Cooperation’: How Sam Bankman-Fried Tried to Cling to FTX
articles.snippet: Emails and text messages show how lawyers and executives struggled to persuade the 30-year-old entrepreneur to give up control of his collapsing crypto exchange.
articles.abstract: Emails and text messages show how lawyers and executives struggled to persuade the 30-year-old entrepreneur to give up control of his collapsing crypto exchange.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the cryptocurrency exchange FTX filed for bankruptcy on Nov. 11, the company’s founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, announced the news in a contrite message on Twitter.

articles.headline: Proud, Scared and Conflicted. What the China Protesters Told Me.
articles.snippet: In more than a dozen interviews, young people explained how the events of the past few days became what one called a “tipping point.”
articles.abstract: In more than a dozen interviews, young people explained how the events of the past few days became what one called a “tipping point.”
articles.lead_paragraph: They went to their first demonstrations. They chanted their first protest slogans. They had their first encounters with the police.

articles.headline: Chinese Protests Over ‘Zero Covid’ Follow Months of Economic Pain
articles.snippet: President Xi Jinping’s unbending approach to the pandemic has hurt businesses and strangled growth, squeezing the world’s second-largest economy.
articles.abstract: President Xi Jinping’s unbending approach to the pandemic has hurt businesses and strangled growth, squeezing the world’s second-largest economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The toll of China’s unwavering approach to fighting Covid has rippled through the world’s second-largest economy for months: Youth unemployment reached a record 20 percent, corporate profits sagged, and economic growth fell well below Beijing’s own projections.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Olivia Wang and Joy Dong

articles.headline: With Federal Aid on the Table, Utilities Shift to Embrace Climate Goals
articles.snippet: As billions in government subsidies were at stake, the electric utility industry shed its opposition to clean-air regulation and put its lobbying muscle behind passing President Biden’s climate bill.
articles.abstract: As billions in government subsidies were at stake, the electric utility industry shed its opposition to clean-air regulation and put its lobbying muscle behind passing President Biden’s climate bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just two years ago, DTE Energy, a Michigan-based electric utility, was still enmeshed in a court fight with federal regulators over emissions from a coal-burning power plant on the western shore of Lake Erie that ranks as one of the nation’s largest sources of climate-changing air pollution.

articles.headline: With Intimidation and Surveillance, China Tries to Snuff Out Protests
articles.snippet: Communist Party officials are using decades-old tactics, along with some new ones, to quash the most widespread protests in decades. But Xi Jinping is silent.
articles.abstract: Communist Party officials are using decades-old tactics, along with some new ones, to quash the most widespread protests in decades. But Xi Jinping is silent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reacting to China’s boldest and most widespread protests in decades, the security apparatus built by Communist Party leader Xi Jinping is mobilizing on multiple fronts to quash dissent, drawing on its decades-old tool kit of repression and surveillance.

articles.headline: Congressional Leaders Say They Will Act to Prevent Rail Strike
articles.snippet: Democratic and Republican leaders prepared to intercede as President Biden warned the prospect of a December strike put the U.S. economy “at risk.”
articles.abstract: Democratic and Republican leaders prepared to intercede as President Biden warned the prospect of a December strike put the U.S. economy “at risk.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democratic and Republican leaders in Congress vowed on Tuesday to pass legislation averting a nationwide rail strike, saying they agreed with President Biden that a work stoppage during the holidays next month would disrupt shipping and deal a devastating blow to the nation’s economy.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Emily Cochrane
